body: Already squash all commit. Actually I did a rebase this afternoon but tests still failing. Also I found those failures also happens on master, this is so sad :(

Having done some reading and performed a bit of a survey of some other (bigish) packages, my recommendation is that we pin to a known, working state in `requirements.txt` for development; and not pin in `setup.py` for distribution; we should probably test against both.

This is based on the following findings:

ipython - not pinned: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/setup.py#L200
pytest - not pinned: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/master/setup.py#L51
pylons - not pinned: https://github.com/Pylons/pyramid/blob/master/setup.py#L40
django - not pinned: https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/setup.py#L50
sympy - not pinned: https://github.com/sympy/sympy/blob/master/setup.py#L365
requests - setup.py not pinned: https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/blob/master/setup.py#L49
requests - requirements.txt pinned: https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/blob/master/requirements.txt#L1
boto3 - setup.py not pinned: https://github.com/boto/boto3/blob/develop/setup.py
boto3 - requirements.txt pinned: https://github.com/boto/boto3/blob/develop/requirements.txt
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1806

@skudriashev : I tried doing that, but PEP8 prescribes to not use spaces when the equals sign is used as a keyword argument or default parameter value: 

> Don't use spaces around the = sign when used to indicate a keyword argument or a default parameter value.

The first one is a basic assignment. I'm not sure if one of the options of PEP8 is turned off?

E251 unexpected spaces around keyword / parameter equals

If that warning is turned off, I'll make the change and move forward.

Can you please provide more details around what is NOT working.

For me, in master, trying the following seems to work just fine:

``` python
from airflow import configuration
configuration.conf.remove_option('core', 'sql_alchemy_conn')
configuration.conf.set('core', 'sql_alchemy_conn_cmd', 'echo foo bar baz')
configuration.get('core', 'sql_alchemy_conn')  # returns b'foo bar baz\n'
```
@gwax thanks for gathering the evidence! You have me convinced.
we don't seem to have a `requirements.txt`?

The exception which I attached in [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-610) occurred when I've made a change to the configuration to use _sql_alchemy_conn_cmd_.
Originally it was _sql_alchemy_conn_ and I created databases with this option by _airflow initdb_.

You can see this invalid operation with following steps.
1.  create an airflow.cfg file:

```
[core]
sql_alchemy_conn_cmd = /home/airflow/db_conn.sh
```
1. _/home/airflow/db_conn.sh_ contains:

```
#!/bin/bash
printf mysql+mysqldb://airflow:airflow@localhost:3306/airflow
```
1. you need to run _airflow initdb_

```
$ airflow initdb
[2016-11-01 09:54:18,041] {__init__.py:57} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor
[2016-11-01 09:54:18,114] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python2.7/lib2to3/Grammar.txt
[2016-11-01 09:54:18,132] {driver.py:120} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python2.7/lib2to3/PatternGrammar.txt
DB: sqlite:////home/airflow/airflow.db
[2016-11-01 09:54:18,382] {db.py:284} INFO - Creating tables
....
```

Although _sql_alchemy_conn_cmd_ is exists, airflow is trying to create db using sqlite.

I think default configuration precedes over __cmd_ configurations.
Your test needs to override default options instead of deleting them.

The test code is inappropriate to test it. I'll change the code and pull request again.

@gtoonstra, I've tried locally:

``` bash
$ pip install flake8
$ pip freeze
...
flake8==3.0.4
```

``` bash
$ flake8 airflow/contrib/hooks/datadog_hook.py
...
tmp.py:58:48: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator                                                                                                                                                                             
tmp.py:98:20: E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
...
```

Fixing this two lines make linting pass fine.

Allright, flake8 wasn't failing for me because since 2012 E226 is ignored by default. I had to enable this with --select=E226 to get flake8 to complain. Probably you've got this configured on by default. Should be fixed now.

I believe Variable.set does that for us... And no new code...

Get Outlook for iOS

On Wed, Nov 2, 2016 at 12:42 PM -0700, "George Leslie-Waksman" notifications@github.com wrote:

@gwax commented on this pull request.

In airflow/models.py:

> -        Like a Python builtin dict object, setdefault returns the current value
> -        for a key, and if it isn't there, stores the default value and returns it.
>   +
> -        :param key: Dict key for this Variable
> -        :type key: String
> -        :param: default: Default value to set and return if the variable
> -        isn't already in the DB
> -        :type: default: Mixed
> -        :param: deserialize_json: Store this as a JSON encoded value in the DB
> -         and un-encode it when retrieving a value
> -        :return: Mixed
> -        """
> -        obj = session.query(cls).filter(cls.key == key).first()
> -        if obj is None:
> -            if default is not None:
> -                Variable.set(key, default, serialize_json=deserialize_json)

do we need to commit the session?

Oh noes, my last comment disappeared, copy-pasting below:

In that case it would be safer to use a proper sentinel instead of an empty dict:

``` python
default_sentinel = object()
obj = Variable.get(key, default_var=default_sentinel)  # deserialize_json=False is the default, right?
if obj is default_sentinel:
    ...
```

Though, at this point, maybe it's better to ask forgiveness rather than permission:

``` python
try:
    return Variable.get(key, deserialize_json=deserialize_json)
except ValueError:
    Variable.set(key, default_var, serialize_json=deserialize_json)
    return default_var
```

(as an aside, looking at this says to me that `Variable.get` should be raising a `KeyError` instead of a `ValueError`)

Gotcha. I see and understand the problem now.

It feels to me like patching the `read` method isn't quite the right way to go. What we want is for the behavior of `get` to read defaults after `_cmd` configurations. What your patch does is remove all configuration variables that match a `_cmd` from the defaults. This creates the potential problem of using a `_cmd`, removing it, and then no longer having the default to fall back to.

Could you, instead, create a second parser for defaults, perhaps `self.defaults = ConfigParser()` inside `__init__`, load `DEFAULT_CONFIG` into there, and modify `read` to check `self.defaults` after `_cmd` but before failing?
+1 I'll go ahead and squash on merge.

@felipetancredo Will #1806 work for you? I think as a matter of style we prefer to have all logic encapsulated inside the operator. It's true that you can always interact with any operator from the DAGfile, as you demonstrate in your example, but it's harder to document/example/test.
Also, since this is part of cold case PR clean-ups, I need an ETA for a fix? I need a response within the next 5 days.

Changes made, commits squashed.

You can probably do all of your testing by instantiating a ConfigParserWithDefaults object to test against. Then you can feed in just the subset of the config and defaults that you want to test against.

@criccomini @artwr 
Would still like to add this feature if you guys think it appropriate. Please let me know how we should proceed.

Travis tests methods within tox environment which provides environment variables including backends information that always precedes other config fed in. So It makes tricky to test `_cmd` configurations.

Yes, travis and tox will feed a bunch of stuff in that is likely to override existing parameters but you can use entirely independent parameters.

With a little bit of work, you can do something like:

``` python
TEST_CONFIG = """
[conf_testing]
thing1 = thing1_conf
thing3_cmd = "printf cmd_result"
"""
TEST_DEFAULTS = """
[conf_testing]
thing2 = thing2_default
thing3 = thing3_default
"""

test_conf = AirflowConfigParser(defaults=TEST_DEFAULTS)
test_conf.read(TEST_CONFIG)
test_conf.as_command_stdout = test_conf.as_command_stdout | {
    ('conf_testing', 'thing3'),
}
```

@r39132 we need to support the old behaviour since people seem to rely on it. this means we need 2 signals to tell airflow to either

1) wait for tasks to finish, then terminate
2) kill child tasks, then terminate

AFAICT there's no standard way to indicate this; I would like some ideas from commiters/the community as to which signals to choose
